Rule.title: Check for Presence of User .rhosts Files

description.p: While no .rhosts files are shipped with CentOS 7, users can easily create them.

rationale.p: This action is only meaningful if .rhosts support is permitted in the file /etc/pam.conf. Even though the .rhosts files are ineffective if support is disabled in /etc/pam.conf, they may have been brought over from other systems and could contain information useful to an attacker for those other systems.

p.p: If any users have .rhosts files determine why they have them.

description.p: Over time, system administration errors and changes can lead to groups being defined in /etc/passwd but not in /etc/group.

rationale.p: Groups defined in the /etc/passwd file but not in the /etc/group file pose a threat to system security since group permissions are not properly managed.

p.p: Analyze the output of the Audit step above and perform the appropriate action to correct any discrepancies found.

Rule.title: Check That Users Are Assigned Valid Home Directories

description.p: Users can be defined in /etc/passwd without a home directory or with a home directory does not actually exist.

rationale.p: If the user's home directory does not exist or is unassigned, the user will be placed in "/" and will not be able to write any files or have local environment variables set.

p.p: If any users' home directories do not exist, create them and make sure the respective user owns the directory. Users without assigned should be removed or assigned a home directory as appropriate.

description.p: The user home directory is space defined for the particular user to set local environment variables and to store personal files.

rationale.p: Since the user is accountable for files stored in the user home directory, the user must be the owner of the directory.

p.p: Change the ownership any home directories that are not owned by the defined user to the correct user.

description.p: Although the useradd program will not let you create a duplicate User ID (UID), it is possible for an administrator to manually edit the /etc/passwd file and change the UID field.

rationale.p: Users must be assigned unique UIDs for accountability and to ensure appropriate access protections.

p.p: Based on the results of the script, establish unique UIDs and review all files owned by the shared UID to determine which UID they are supposed to belong to.

description.p: Although the groupadd program will not let you create a duplicate Group ID (GID), it is possible for an administrator to manually edit the /etc/group file and change the GID field.

rationale.p: User groups must be assigned unique GIDs for accountability and to ensure appropriate access protections.

Note: In the case of extremely large groups it can become necessary to split a GID across group names due to character limits per line. Any such instances should be carefully audited, unless absolutely necessary such instances should be avoided.

p.p: Based on the results of the script, establish unique GIDs and review all files owned by the shared GID to determine which group they are supposed to belong to.

Rule.title: Check That Reserved UIDs Are Assigned to System Accounts

description.p: Traditionally, UNIX systems establish "reserved" UIDs (0-999 range) that are intended for system accounts.

rationale.p: If a user is assigned a UID that is in the reserved range, even if it is not presently in use, security exposures can arise if a subsequently installed application uses the same UID.

p.p: Based on the results of the script, change any UIDs that are in the reserved range to one that is in the user range. Review all files owned by the reserved UID to determine which UID they are supposed to belong to.

description.p: Although the useradd program will not let you create a duplicate user name, it is possible for an administrator to manually edit the /etc/passwd file and change the user name.

rationale.p: If a user is assigned a duplicate user name, it will create and have access to files with the first UID for that username in /etc/passwd. For example, if "test4" has a UID of 1000 and a subsequent "test4" entry has a UID of 2000, logging in as "test4" will use UID 1000. Effectively, the UID is shared, which is a security problem.

p.p: Based on the results of the script, establish unique user names for the users. File ownerships will automatically reflect the change as long as the users have unique UIDs.

description.p: Although the groupadd program will not let you create a duplicate group name, it is possible for an administrator to manually edit the /etc/group file and change the group name.

rationale.p: If a group is assigned a duplicate group name, it will create and have access to files with the first GID for that group in /etc/group. Effectively, the GID is shared, which is a security problem.

p.p: Based on the results of the script, establish unique names for the user groups. File group ownerships will automatically reflect the change as long as the groups have unique GIDs.

Rule.title: Check for Presence of User .netrc Files

description.p: The .netrc file contains data for logging into a remote host for file transfers via FTP.

rationale.p: The .netrc file presents a significant security risk since it stores passwords in unencrypted form. Even if FTP is disabled, user accounts may have brought over .netrc files from other systems which could pose a risk to those systems.

p.p: Making global modifications to users' files without alerting the user community can result in unexpected outages and unhappy users. Therefore, it is recommended that a monitoring policy be established to report user .netrc files and determine the action to be taken in accordance with site policy.

Rule.title: Check for Presence of User .forward Files

description.p: The .forward file specifies an email address to forward the user's mail to.

rationale.p: Use of the .forward file poses a security risk in that sensitive data may be inadvertently transferred outside the organization. The .forward file also poses a risk as it can be used to execute commands that may perform unintended actions.

p.p: Making global modifications to users' files without alerting the user community can result in unexpected outages and unhappy users. Therefore, it is recommended that a monitoring policy be established to report user .forward files and determine the action to be taken in accordance with site policy.
